title: Declaring drought fasts
vignette: Rains are weeks late. Leaders debate announcing community fasts immediately or waiting a short time to see if weather shifts naturally.

options.text: Start fasting right away to plead for mercy.
Wait; fasting too soon burdens the people.

title: Builders versus prayer rally
vignette: Construction workers are midway through a roof pour when a noon drought-prayer service starts. Halt the job to join or continue and pray privately later?

options.text: Yes; join the prayer with everyone else.
Continue working and pray privately later.

title: Individual fasting without the community
vignette: A pious man wants to fast for rain even though the community has not decreed it. Others worry it looks presumptuous.

options.text: Let him fast privately if he wishes.
Discourage private fasting until the community joins.

title: Sharing distressing dreams aloud
vignette: On a public fast people sometimes describe anxiety dreams so the crowd prays for them. Others feel publicising dreams is embarrassing. Which practice wins?

options.text: Announce to mobilize support.
Keep dreams private; pray silently.

title: Voluntary extra hours of fasting
vignette: A local fast runs sunriseâ€“sunset. One participant wants to start the previous evening as a personal upgrade. Allow or discourage adding private stringency?

options.text: He may begin fasting from nightfall voluntarily.
He should eat at night; adding restrictions is unnecessary.

title: Wearing shoes on communal fasts
vignette: Some participants remove leather shoes as on Yom Kippur. Others argue that weekday fasts don't require this level of affliction.

options.text: Remove leather shoes to increase humility.
Keep shoes on; only Yom Kippur demands it.

title: Parading the Ark outdoors
vignette: During extreme drought, some suggest carrying the community's sacred scroll chest into the square as a dramatic prayer gesture. Others fear disrespect or damage. Move it or keep it indoors?

options.text: Bring it out to inspire repentance.
Keep it inside to preserve its honor.

title: Eulogies on a fast day
vignette: A revered elder dies on a designated fast. Hold short eulogies today despite low energy or postpone full tributes until the fast ends?

options.text: Hold brief eulogies today despite fasting.
Delay until tomorrow to maintain focus on prayer.

title: senior professionals drinking wine during drought
vignette: Cohanim normally abstain from wine when the central complex might need them. In exile, is this still necessary during public fasts for rain?

options.text: Abstain as a sign of readiness and mourning.
They may drink; no central complex service is imminent.

title: Rains arrive midday
vignette: Heavy rain finally falls at noon of the scheduled fast. End fasting at once in gratitude or finish the day's fast as pledged?

options.text: End the fast and rejoice immediately.
Finish the day to complete the commitment.

title: Solidarity fast for neighbouring region
vignette: A nearby city declares a drought fast. Our area has water. Join in solidarity or focus on local welfare only?

options.text: Yes; unite in their distress.
No; focus on our local needs only.

title: Celebrating after a drought breaks
vignette: Once the rains finally fall, some propose a festive meal that night. Others say it diminishes the serious mood of the fast series.

options.text: Hold a small celebration of thanks.
Wait a few days before partying.

title: Charity instead of fasting
vignette: A wealthy donor proposes feeding the poor rather than everyone fasting for rain. Accept charity swap or insist the fast itself is essential?

options.text: Yes; charity may replace fasting this time.
No; fasting together is essential.

title: Continuing unsuccessful fast cycles
vignette: Multiple fast rounds brought no rain. Keep adding more or pause to reassess strategy first?

options.text: Continue fasting until relief comes.
Pause and seek other solutions first.

title: Fasting on a minor holiday
vignette: A couple schedules a personal fast to atone for misdeeds, but it coincides with a minor festival where fasting is discouraged.

options.text: Fast anyway for personal repentance.
Postpone to respect the festive day.
